name: Pokimane Permanently Banned on Twitch
description: Imane Anys, better known as Pokimane, is a popular twitch streamer who was recently banned for streaming episodes of The Last Avatar. This happened when Nickelodeon issued a DMCA take down on her stream.

And then, you know, if that's illegal, then you need to define what makes legal and illegal content
And that's where fair use comes into play
I think the American law is old, but it's good
And the problem is, is that to get a fair use ruling, you need a judge to make a call on it
And weigh all these different options of fair use, and there's four factors of fair use, which I'll read to you
And then, you know, it becomes really litigious and it becomes a whole thing
But, like, how are you supposed to weigh the options here?
You know, first one, the purpose and character of the use, including whether it is commercial in nature or for non-profit educational purposes
So they're saying, have you reproduced this content to simply make money or are you having like a good intention to educate
A good example would be like a dude selling VHSs on the street or DVDs on the street of bootleg movies

Versus somebody in a classroom who plays a video so that he gives context to a bigger conversation

You know, these are important to consider
The nature of the copyrighted work
Using material from primary factual work is more likely to be fair use than purely fictional work

In the context of educational and newsworthy purposes
Whereas if it's fictional basically
It's harder to add a good new context to a fictional work

And then, so those two factors are not that important
The third factor is extremely important
This is the one that most judges really come down on
The amount and sustainability... sorry, the amount and substantiality of the portion used in relation to the copyrighted work as a whole
So they're saying this says, borrowing small bits of material from an original work is more likely to be considered fair use than borrowing large portions
However, even a small taking may weigh against fair use in some situation if it constitutes the heart of the work
So basically they're saying, this really comes down to, did you use more than you needed to create your new work?
Or did you use as little as possible to make your point?
Now when you look at the lawsuit we won against Matt Haas
I don't remember the facts, he says, well, almost 50% of his video

So it uses that harm the copyright owner's ability to profit from his or her original work by serving as a replacement for demand for that work
That's less likely to be fair use. So what they're saying is if the content you're making is a substitute for the original, then you're in trouble
You got to make it so that people watching your video would never
